search_parameters.q: what is the employment relations act 1999

search_information.query_displayed: what is the employment relations act 1999

knowledge_graph.title: Employment Relations Act 1999
knowledge_graph.description: The Employment Relations Act 1999 is an act of Parliament of the United Kingdom. It made significant amendments in UK labour law to the Trade Union and Labour Relations Act 1992.
knowledge_graph.introduced_by: Stephen Byers, Secretary of State for Trade and Industry

introduced_by_links.text: Stephen Byers, Secretary of State for Trade and Industry

related_questions.question: What is the purpose of the Employment Relations Act?
related_questions.snippet: The Basics of the Employment Relations Act. The main purpose of the Act is to ensure that employment relationships are conducted with good faith. This focuses heavily on the trust between yourself, as the employer and your employees.
related_questions.title: Understanding the Employment Relations Act | LegalVision NZ

related_questions.question: What is the Employment Relations Act 1999 blacklist?
related_questions.snippet: These Regulations generally prohibit the compilation, use, sale or supply of blacklists containing details of trade union members and activists whose purpose is to discriminate against workers on grounds of trade union membership or trade union activities (regulation 3).
related_questions.title: The Employment Relations Act 1999 (Blacklists) Regulations 2010

related_questions.question: What did the employment Act do?
related_questions.snippet: The Employment Act of 1946 mandated the contradictory policy goals of seeking both full employment and low inflation. The Act established the president's Council of Economic Advisors to help maintain these policy goals at the executive level.
related_questions.title: Employment Act Of 1946: What It Is, How It Works, History - Investopedia

related_questions.question: What is the major purpose of the Labour Relations Act?
related_questions.snippet: It establishes a framework that promotes fair treatment, protects workers' rights, and encourages collective bargaining. It also provides a mechanism for resolving disputes, which helps maintain harmonious industrial relations.
related_questions.title: Understanding the Labour Relations Act - Pagel Schulenburg Attorneys
